Moscow 117198 Russia Peoples Friendship University of Russia (RUDN University), 6 Miklukho Maklaya str., 117198, Moscow, Russian Federation f Universidad ECOTEC, Km 13.5 Samborondón, Samborondón EC0922302, Ecuador Universidad ECOTEC Km 13.5 Samborondón Samborondón EC0922302 Ecuador Universidad ECOTEC, Km 13.5 Samborondón, Samborondón EC0922302, Ecuador ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 The contributions of these authors are equal In this study, kaolin waste was functionalized with sulfonic groups to enhance its textural and chemical properties, resulting in a high-performance heterogeneous catalyst. The functionalized material was thoroughly characterized using various techniques, including FTIR, XRD, TGA, BET (N2-physisorption), and TEM-EDX. The incorporation of sulfonic groups introduced active sites that significantly increased the ion exchange capacity, thereby enhancing the catalytic performance. When employed as a catalyst in the acetalization of benzaldehyde, the functionalized kaolin waste achieved a remarkable conversion rate of 98 % under optimized conditions. The successful transformation of kaolin waste into a highly effective catalyst demonstrates its potential for broader applications in green chemistry, particularly in sustainable synthesis. Acetals, the target products, are crucial intermediates in organic synthesis and the pharmaceutical industry. The catalytic process proposed in this study offers an efficient and environmentally friendly approach to acetal formation, advancing the field of heterogeneous catalysis. Additionally, extending the application of this functionalized material to other challenging reactions could further highlight its versatility and potential as a sustainable catalyst in various industrial processes. Graphical Abstract Keywords Catalyst Kaolin waste Sulfonic groups Acetalization Green catalyst Amazon Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The acetalization is a chemical reaction that involves converting carbonyl compounds (aldehydes) into an acetal by adding two equivalent of alcohol [44]. Acetals are versatile organic compounds widely utilized across various sectors, from organic synthesis to polymer and fuel production [20,44]. The transformation into acetal can stabilize reactive molecules, enabling the temporary protection of sensitive functional groups during synthesis [41]. Additionally, acetals can be conveniently removed under controlled conditions to restore the original functionality of the molecule, making this strategy particularly advantageous in synthesizing complex compounds [20]. Recently, benzaldehyde has emerged as an alternative for producing bio-additives [10]. Commonly used alcohols in benzaldehyde acetalization include polar protic solvents such as methanol, and ethanol [5,40,46]. However, methanol stands out due to its economic feasibility, wide availability, and its efficacy as a methyl group donor, promoting the formation of stable and reactive acetals [22]. Employing a catalyst in the acetalization reaction offers the advantage of promoting the selective formation of desired acetals while minimizing the generation of undesirable by-products and enhancing overall product yields [8]. Typically, acetalization reactions are conducted with acidic homogeneous catalysts [10], however, due to their environmental drawbacks, such as inability to be reclaimed from the reaction system, researchers have explored diverse heterogeneous acid catalysts [20,41]. In this context, zeolites [27,34], metal–organic frameworks [17], polymers [25], have been studied as effective solid support matrices for heterogeneous catalysis. In line with the demand for environmentally friendly catalysts and waste reduction, this study introduces a novel catalyst derived from thermochemically functionalized kaolin waste. Kaolin is one of the significant ores in the global mining landscape, being responsible for generating $156.7 million in exports solely in the Brazilian scenario in 2022 [24](https://panoramamineracao.com.br/pmb2023/). This ore is characterized by being a white rock predominantly composed of kaolinite and has various industrial applications, particularly in paper manufacturing [29,39]. For commercial use, kaolin needs to undergo a beneficiation process aimed at removing impurities and making it suitable for applications, which generates waste that can cause significant environmental impacts (de Nazaré [14,19,42]). The kaolin residue generated still contains high concentrations of kaolinite, along with other residual minerals, and can be used as a source of aluminosilicates for the synthesis of heterogeneous catalysts [13,16,15,19,26,35], thus reducing production costs and promoting valorization of this residue. By using heterogeneous catalysts instead of homogeneous ones, it is possible to obtain several advantages, including easy handling, simple recovery, and reuse of the catalyst [1,21]. The use of sulfonic acids (−SO3H) in the synthesis of solid catalysts aims to increase catalytic activity [11]. Thus, in this study, 3-mercaptopropyltrimethoxysilane (MTPS) was anchored into the kaolin waste and its sulfonic form was obtained after the oxidation of the thiol group (−SH), as previously described [12,26,36]. The anchoring of this organosulfonic group provides an increase in the hydrophobicity of the material, reported in the literature as highly efficient organic-inorganic hybrid catalysts [18,36]. In this study, benzaldehyde acetalization in the presence of methanol to produce stable acetals at room temperature was catalyzed using a material derived from kaolin waste. The catalyst was synthesized and functionalized through a straightforward process, ensuring the production of a high-value-added product. This marks a significant advancement in the catalytic process, improving efficiency, selectivity, and reducing the reliance on expensive catalysts, while simultaneously valorizing environmentally impactful waste materials. The anchoring of this organosulfonic group increases the hydrophobicity of the material and has been reported in the literature as a key feature in highly efficient organic-inorganic hybrid catalysts [18,36]. In this study, benzaldehyde acetalization with methanol was performed at room temperature using a novel catalyst derived from kaolin waste, functionalized via a straightforward and low-cost route. This strategy enables the production of a high-value-added product while valorizing an environmentally burdensome industrial residue. In this context, the present work proposes an innovative approach that employs kaolin waste, an abundant and low-cost industrial by-product, as the precursor for the synthesis of a highly efficient heterogeneous catalyst. Unlike previous reports using purified kaolinite or commercial aluminosilicates [49,50], this study demonstrates a valorization pathway for waste materials, integrating calcination, acid leaching, and surface sulfonation steps. The resulting MKL-SO₃ catalyst exhibits strong Brønsted acidity and remarkable catalytic performance in acetalization reactions. Furthermore, the process described herein combines sustainability and performance, offering a compelling alternative to conventional sulfonated resins and mesostructured silicas. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report that integrates kaolin waste valorization with sulfonic acid functionalization for fine chemical synthesis, making a significant contribution to the development of green catalytic processes. 2 Experimental analysis 2.1 Materials and equipment All the chemicals used in this work, were extra pure analytical grade and were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Ultrapure water (18.2 MΩ cm−1) from a Milli-Q ultrapure system was used. Kaolin waste, obtained from CADAM S.A., was ground in a mill, sieved through 200 mesh sieves and stored in room temperature. Gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC-MS) analyses were performed on a HP5-MS capillary column (L = 30 m, Ø = 0.32 μm, film = 0.25 mm) by using a GC-MS system (Shimadzu, Japan). The carrier gas was helium at a constant flow rate of 24.3 mL/min. For the setup of each system, 1 μL of the GC sample was injected with a split–splitless injector. The oven temperature started at 60 °C (held for 2 min) and then was increased up to 240 °C (maintained for 15 min), with a heating speed of 10 °C/min. The mass spectrometer operated in electron ionization mode at 70 eV and mass spectra were obtained in a molecular mass range (m/z) of 40–660. Compound identification was performed by comparison of the obtained spectra with the US National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) mass spectral library (ver. 2023). The reaction products were quantified using an off-line Gas Chromatography-Flame Ionization Detector (GC-FID, Shimadzu, Japan), equipped with an HP-5 capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm i.d., film thickness 1.8 μm). The injection volume was 1 μL in split mode, with a split ratio of 20:1. Helium was used as the carrier gas at a flow rate of 1.0 mL/min. The oven temperature was initially set at 50 °C and maintained for 2 min, followed by a linear ramp of 10 °C/min to 200 °C, held for 10 min. The total runtime was 36 min. The injector and detector temperatures were maintained at 250 °C. All reactions were run in duplicate to ensure reproducibility. 2.2 Synthesis of catalyst The kaolin waste was subjected to calcination in a muffle oven at 750 ºC for 5 h. The resulting metakaolin was then activated in a reflux system using 2.5 M sulfuric acid at a ratio of 1:10 (metakaolin to acid) for 2 h, maintaining a temperature of 90 ºC with continuous stirring. After filtration, the leached metakaolin (MKL) was rinsed with 100 mL of a 0.5 M sulfuric acid solution and thoroughly washed with water until the pH approached 7. Subsequently, the metakaolin leachate was dried in an oven. Next, the metakaolin underwent functionalization with 3-mercaptopropyltrimethoxysilane (MTPS). For each gram of metakaolin leachate, 5 mmol of MTPS and 30 mL of toluene were used in a reflux system. The reaction proceeded for 4 h under constant stirring at a temperature of 110 ºC. The resulting material was filtered, rinsed with 50 mL of toluene, followed by approximately 2 L of water, and then dried in the oven at 100 ºC. For each gram of functionalized metakaolin, 17 mL of 35 % hydrogen peroxide were added to a sealed amber flask and maintained under constant stirring for 12 h. Subsequently, the material was washed with 50 mL of ethanol, followed by distilled water, and dried in the oven, resulting in kaolin waste functionalized with sulfonic groups named hereafter as MKL-SO3. The parameters adopted for each step of the synthesis were selected based on established protocols and adapted to maximize surface activation and functional group incorporation. The calcination at 750 °C for 5 h ensures complete dehydroxylation and formation of reactive amorphous metakaolin [2,43]. The acid leaching conditions (2.5 M H₂SO₄, 90 °C, 2 h, 1:10 ratio) promote the removal of aluminum and the enrichment of silica, as optimized in previous works [19,26]. The conditions for functionalization with MTPS (110 °C, 4 h in refluxing toluene) are consistent with established organosilane grafting protocols [12,18]. Finally, the oxidation with 35 % H₂O₂ for 12 h has been shown to efficiently convert thiol groups to sulfonic acid moieties without structural degradation [36,49]. 2.3 Characterization method The properties of the raw materials and the obtained catalyst were studied by several characterization techniques. The analysis of chemical composition was conducted using Energy Dispersive Spectrometry (EDS) with a Shimadzu Ray EDX-700 Spectrometer. Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) were conducted using a ThermoScience instrument, Nicolet iS5 model, within the absorption range of 4000–400 cm-1, with the samples compressed into KBr pellets. X-ray Diffraction (XRD) was carried out using a diffractometer Bruker D8 Advanced, under conditions of 40 kV and 40 mA, radiation CuKa (λ=1.5406), scan rate of 0.2º/0.2 s within a range of 2θ from 0.5 to 80º. Thermogravimetric analyses were conducted using a SHIMADZU thermobalance (TGA-DTA), DTG-60H model, under a synthetic air atmosphere with a flow rate of 50 mL/min, in the temperature range of 25°C to 1000 °C, and a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The adsorption and desorption isotherms of N2 were obtained using the TriStar II equipment (Micromeritics), the samples underwent a pre-treatment at 200 °C for 2 h. The surface area was determined using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, the pore volume and pore size distribution were determined using the Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. 2.4 Standard procedure for acetalization and product analysis To assess the catalytic performance of the synthesized green catalysts, a batch experiment was conducted at room temperature under continuous agitation. In this trial, a typical reaction involving benzaldehyde (3 mmol) acetalization was performed by using an excess of methanol. All solutions were prepared in 9 mL of methanol, maintaining an excess of alcohol with respect to aldehyde, and magnetic stirring was initiated at the beginning of the reaction. The reactions were conducted under room temperature conditions, and samples were taken at different time intervals. The conversion and selectivity of the reactions were determined by GC-FID while qualitative identifications of the product structures were assigned by GC-MS. 2.5 Catalyst recyclability To assess the catalytic performance of the synthesized green catalysts, a batch experiment was conducted at room temperature under continuous agitation. In this trial, a typical reaction involving benzaldehyde (3 mmol) acetalization was performed by using an excess of methanol. All solutions were prepared in 9 mL of methanol, maintaining an excess of alcohol with respect to aldehyde, and magnetic stirring was initiated at the beginning of the reaction. The reactions were conducted under room temperature conditions, and samples were taken at different time intervals. The conversion and selectivity of the reactions were determined by GC-FID while qualitative identifications of the product structures were assigned by GC-MS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization data The synthesis steps of MKL-SO₃ are illustrated in Scheme 1 (see Scheme 1 for experimental details). The first step involves the thermochemical treatment of kaolin waste, the raw material undergoes calcination to disrupt the crystalline structure, transforming into metakaolin, which is then leached to remove impurities and subsequently referred to as MKL. To enhance the catalytic performance of the synthesized material, a functionalization process with MTPS was developed (2nd step), followed by an oxidation of the thiol groups into sulfonic groups (3rd step). The catalyst synthesized with sulfonic groups was named MKL-SO3. The According to EDS measurement compiled in Table 1, kaolin waste exhibit predominant quantities of silicon and aluminum, indicating the presence of the mineral kaolinite [26]. However, the concentrations of iron and titanium in the residue suggest the presence of accessory minerals, such as anatase (TiO2) and hematite (Fe2O3) [14,31,36]. After the heat treatment, the raw material is transformed into metakaolin, which becomes more susceptible to acid leaching, resulting in a metakaolin leached (MKL), a material with a high silica content [4,14]. In the MKL-SO3 sample, a significant increase in SO3 is evident, indicating a successful functionalization and oxidation of MTPS. The significant increase in SO₃ content observed in the MKL-SO₃ sample (6.13 wt%) compared to MKL (0.26 wt%) provides strong evidence of successful surface functionalization with sulfonic acid groups. Additionally, the substantial increase in SiO₂ in MKL (93.14 wt%) after acid leaching reflects the efficient removal of aluminum and other cations, resulting in a highly siliceous matrix, which is favorable for covalent bonding with organosilane precursors. Based on the EDS results, the sulfur content in the MKL-SO₃ catalyst corresponds to approximately 6.13 wt% of SO₃. Assuming full conversion of sulfur into sulfonic acid groups, this represents an estimated acid site density of ∼0.77 mmol –SO₃H/g. This value is consistent with those reported for sulfonated mesoporous catalysts [49,50], reinforcing the strong Brønsted acidity of the material and its excellent catalytic performance. The X-ray diffraction patterns of the kaolin waste and the leached metakaolin (MKL) can be seen in the Fig. 1. The diffraction pattern of the waste exhibits two prominent basal reflections, situated at 12.25° and 24.77° in 2θ, corresponding to the primary characteristic peaks of kaolinite [3,7]. Other peaks of lower intensity were also detected in 21.01°, 26.34° and 35.78°, indicating the presence of common kaolin impurities such as goethite (FeO(OH)), anatase (TiO2) and hematite (Fe2O3), respectively [1,26]. The XRD patterns of MKL clearly indicate the transformation of the raw material into an amorphous substance, confirming the pyrolytic process that occurred. A broad band between 15°-30° in 2θ corresponds to the presence of amorphous silica, replacing the kaolinite peaks. The distinctive peak at approximately 26.34° in 2θ corresponds to the presence of anatase [26]; Brito et al., 2021. The findings from the XRD analysis align with the EDS results provided above. The disappearance of kaolinite’s characteristic reflections and the emergence of a broad halo between 15°–30° 2θ confirm the successful transformation into an amorphous metakaolinite phase. This structural disorder enhances the surface reactivity, facilitating the anchoring of functional groups in later steps. The persistence of anatase and minor hematite peaks suggests the retention of thermally stable impurities, which could act as textural promoters or Lewis acid sites, contributing synergistically to the observed catalytic activity. The Fig. 2 shows the infrared absorption spectra of metakaolin leachate (MKL) and the catalyst (MKL-SO3). The band at around 3400 cm⁻¹ can be ascribed to the stretching vibration of the O-H groups located between the tetrahedral and octahedral layers of kaolin, these vibrational bands are related to the presence of water and silanol groups in the material [26,37]. The peak observed at approximately 1640 cm⁻¹ is also related to water vibrations and is attributed to the bending mode of O-H groups [38]. Meanwhile, the peaks at 1089 cm⁻¹ and 796 cm⁻¹ are attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of Si-O-Si [47,49], the first one being a characteristic vibration of amorphous silica (Zatta et al., 2010). Another band related to silicon can be observed at 949 cm⁻¹ , associated with Si-O-H stretching [45]. The presence of the sulfonic propyl groups in The significant increase in SO₃ content observed in the MKL-SO can be confirmed by two low-intensity vibrational bands in the range of 3000–2800 cm⁻¹ [32]. In the spectrum of MKL-SO3, these bands occur at approximately 2949 cm⁻¹ and 2884 cm⁻¹ , and they are associated with the asymmetric and symmetric stretching of methylene (-CH2-) groups [32,49]. Low-intensity vibrational bands related to the angular deformation of methylene groups can also occur around 1460 cm⁻¹ , but they are often overlapped by silicon stretching vibrations [32]. Asymmetric stretching vibrations of OS=O can occur around 1170 cm⁻¹ [33,49]. In the catalyst spectrum, there is an overlap of these vibrations with the vibrations related to amorphous silica, forming a broad band, whereas in MKL, this band of silica has a sharper profile. The efficiency of the oxidation of thiol groups (-SH) in MTPS to sulfonic groups can be confirmed by this vibrational band and is consistent with the EDS data, which shows the presence of these groups with higher intensity in the catalyst. Fig. 3(a and b) depict the weight loss profiles and the temperature ranges at which these events occur, comparing the initial material with two derivatives. The raw material exhibits two primary mass losses. The first occurs at ambient temperature up to 250 °C, representing adsorbed water in the material [30], resulting in a minor mass loss of 0.94 %. The next mass loss occurs with a sharp peak of loss at around 505 °C on the DTG curve. This is related to the loss of structural water in kaolinite (Belver at al., 2002), resulting in a loss of 12.11 %. This event is reported in the literature as metakaolinization. It's the temperature range in which chemically bound water in kaolin is lost, converting it into metakaolin. This transformation can begin at temperatures of 300–400 °C and is only completed at temperatures near 600–700 °C (Salahudeen et al., 2018). Metakaolin after the leaching process (MKL) shows a rapid mass loss of approximately 9.9 % when heated from room temperature to 132 °C, which corresponds to the water adsorbed on the material [19]. The second mass loss observed in MKL is gradual and continuous, persisting in the range of 250 °C to 900 °C. This is primarily related to the dehydroxylation of Si(OSi)3OH groups, as well as of cations from remaining elements, both generated during the acid treatment [19]; Belver at al., 2002. The DTG curves of the catalyst display two main mass losses, with the first one being 6.3 %, attributed to the adsorbed water in the material, occurring from room temperature to approximately 200 °C. In this case, the high temperatures required for water desorption may be related to the resonance bonding of the three oxygen atoms in the sulfonic group, which stabilizes the group and hinders the release of water through the hydrogen bonds formed . In the temperature range of 200–600 °C, there is a mass loss of approximately 10 %, which is associated with the decomposition of the sulfonic groups anchored in the material [49]. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for the initial material and its two derivatives are depicted in Fig. 4. The isotherms of raw material exhibited a characteristic as type II, according to IUPAC recommendations, which is typical of materials with low porosity [19,36]. As shown in Table 2, for the leached sample (MKL), a higher specific surface area and a larger pore volume were obtained, possibly due to the degree of aluminum leaching and, consequently, the presence of amorphous silica in the sample (do Nascimento ate al., 2011; [9,48]). After organo-functionalization, the material (MKL-SO3) exhibited a decrease in specific surface area and pore volume, this effect can result from the formation of oxide clusters that have a low surface area and are located at the entrance or inside the pores of the support, causing blockage [9]. However, these values of MKL-SO3 are still higher than those found in the raw material. Fig. 5 displays several representative TEM images. The catalyst exhibits hexagonal or square shapes with well-defined edges. Its structure is amorphous and lacks a crystalline core, in accordance with the XRD outcomes. The EDX analysis reveals a high Si content, as expected along with the other characterization techniques. The TEM micrographs reveal amorphous structures lacking long-range order, consistent with the XRD findings. Such disordered morphologies tend to increase the density of accessible active sites and enhance diffusion phenomena during catalysis. Moreover, the EDX spectrum shows a distinct sulfur signal, corroborating the elemental data from EDS and confirming the successful grafting of sulfonic groups on the surface. This structural configuration is critical for the Brønsted acidity necessary in acetalization reactions. 3.2 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance of the synthesized catalysts was evaluated through batch acetalization of benzaldehyde (BZ) with methanol as the model substrates. In a standard test, the solid catalyst (100 mg) was suspended in 9 mL of methanol, then, 3 mmol of BZ (Scheme 1) and an equivalent amount of nitrobenzene (NB) as internal standard were added. In this condition methanol is playing the role of both solvent and reagent. The mixture was magnetically stirred (500 rpm) at room temperature for 30 min yielding 1,1-dimethoxymethylbenzene ( Scheme 2). This is a step-by-step process involving an intermediate step which is the formation of the hemiacetal ( Scheme 3). The latter then react further to form the complete acetal. Due to the excess of methanol and the strong reactivity of benzaldehyde, the acetal formation process occurs spontaneously and rapidly. Blank measurement was conducted without catalyst to confirm the crucial role of the catalytic system in the reaction progress. As shown in Fig. 6, in absence of catalyst, the conversion to the dimethyl acetal product is negligible. This slight percentage of conversion can potentially be attributed to the presence of a large excess of methanol. At the same time, these results revealed that in the absence of catalyst the conversion was less than 6.1 %, confirming the indispensable role of the catalyst. Interestingly, under the reported reaction conditions, the presence of the expected intermediate hemiacetal or other products such as benzoic acid is not revealed, demonstrating that the kinetic of the second step is higher than the first, implying that the catalyst plays a crucial role in ensuring the selectivity of this reaction pathway by converting all the intermediates in product 4. In order to conduct a comprehensive investigation on the catalytic activity, benefits, and drawbacks associated with the process of BZ acetalization, the amount of catalyst, the reaction time and the impacts of the reaction solvent were screened. Another frequently studied factor is temperature, which holds a crucial significance in catalytic processes. However, in this study, the reaction temperature was not investigated due to its spontaneous progression, leading to substantial conversion rates achieved at room temperature. In Fig. 7, is reported the impact of varying amounts of catalyst. As depicted, an increase in catalyst amount results in an enhanced conversion rates reaching a plateau occurs in the range of 100–150 mg. The latter phenomenon could be explained by the sufficient amount of acid active site in the reactor. Thus, adding more than 100 mg of catalysts do not lead to any improvement for the reaction. Fig. 8 shows the effect of reaction time on the studied reaction. As observed, the highest conversion was achieved after 30 min and sustained up to 1 h, resulting in a yield of 98 %. The slight decrease observed after 2–3 h (respectively 94 % and 78 %) could be attributed to the susceptibility to hydrolysis of acetals [23], which can undergo hydrolysis reactions, confirming that acetalization is indeed an equilibrium reaction, and the acetal products can interact with the water generated during the reaction, consequently decreasing the overall product yield. Therefore, looking at the production cost and energy consumption, a reaction time of 30 min seems desirable for the acetalization of BZ with methanol and it was selected as the reference time point for assessing the impact of the substrate. 3.2.1 Type of substrate In our reactions, the alcohol serves as both solvent and reactant. Thus, its nature plays a crucial role on the reaction. Consequently, the impacts of five different alcohols on the BZ acetalization reaction were examined. The summarized findings are depicted in Fig. 9. Among the evaluated solvents, methanol exhibited the highest conversion rate (98 %), followed by ethanol with a conversion rate of 84.4 %, and ethylene glycol, which reached 82.3 %. In contrast, isopropyl alcohol yielded unexpected outcomes, registering only an 8 % conversion. In agreement with these results, butanol and pentanol lead to conversion below 3 %, suggesting that the acetalization reaction was less favorable in the presence of alcohols with chain lengths exceeding two carbon atoms. The superior performance of methanol and ethanol could be ascribed to their smaller size, enabling enhanced access to the catalyst's active sites and thereby elevating reaction rates. Additionally, their higher acidity might facilitate the catalytic process, further contributing to their notable performance in the reaction. Having established the optimized reaction parameters, a comprehensive exploration of substrate diversity was subsequently undertaken, encompassing a wide variety of aldehydes ( Table 3). The reaction proceeded effectively with both aromatic and aliphatic aldehydes, yielding dimethyl acetals products in favorable to suitable yields. Intriguingly, the heteroaromatic aldehyde exhibited either partial conversion into products or remained unacetalized within these reaction conditions. This could potentially be attributed to the higher basic Lewis nature of heteroatom centers compared to oxygen moieties [28], leading to the unfavorable coordination of the catalyst with these heteroatoms, thereby diminishing its catalytic efficacy. This captivating observation presents an opportunity for the selective acetal protection of a mixture containing heteroaromatic aldehydes. 3.2.2 Catalyst stability As catalyst MKL-SO₃ displayed superior catalytic efficiency in the acetalization of BZ with methanol, its longevity and recyclability were subject to examination. The results for catalyst recyclability under optimized conditions are shown in Fig. 10 (refer to Section 2.5 for the reuse protocol). As depicted in Fig. 10, the catalyst exhibited remarkable durability, with only a slight decline in catalytic performance after five successive experimental rounds. The acetal yield experienced a minor decrease from 98 % in the initial three runs to 77 % in the fifth cycle. These findings indicate that MKL-SO₃ maintains robust catalytic activity over multiple cycles, highlighting its favorable stability and reusability for acetalization reactions. The decline in catalytic activity observed after the fifth cycle may be attributed to several factors. One plausible explanation is the partial leaching of sulfonic acid groups from the catalyst surface during repeated reaction and washing steps, which reduces the number of available Brønsted acid sites [50,49]. Additionally, the accumulation of reaction by-products or strongly adsorbed organic species could contribute to deactivation by blocking active sites or altering the catalyst’s surface properties [51]. This hypothesis is supported by the TGA analysis of the spent catalyst ( Fig. 11), which shows a marked weight loss in the 100–200 °C and 400–600 °C ranges compared to the fresh catalyst (Fig. 3, left panel), whose thermal stability remains higher. Such weight loss suggests the presence of organic residues accumulated on the catalyst surface throughout the reaction cycles, indicating fouling as a major cause of deactivation. 3.2.3 Possible reaction pathway The presented results provide the basis for explaining the role of the catalyst in the reaction process through the proposed reaction pathway (Scheme 3) which suggests that the acetalization of BZ initially occurs through the quick adsorption of BZ onto the catalyst surface [6]. The activation occurred due to the presence of Brønsted acid sites on the surface of the catalyst. The protonated intermediate then reacted with methanol, leading to the formation of a hemiacetal. This step involved immediate deprotonation and protonation, followed by a dehydration process, resulting in the highly reactive oxonium ion. To proceed further, another methanol molecule was introduced to the unstable oxonium ion. After removing a proton, the final acetal product was generated. According with this, the acetal formation followed a typical two-step process, with hemiacetal formation representing a reversible intermediate of the reaction. Surprisingly, the GC-MS analysis did not detect any hemiacetal, indicating that the overall equilibrium of the system tends to the formation of the acetal product. 3.3 Comparative performance with literature catalysts The catalytic performance of MKL-SO₃ was benchmarked against a range of heterogeneous catalysts previously reported for the acetalization of benzaldehyde ( Table 4). Remarkably, MKL-SO₃ exhibited superior activity under significantly milder reaction conditions, achieving 98 % conversion at room temperature within only 30 min, while requiring a comparatively lower catalyst loading. In addition, the catalyst retained 77 % of its initial activity after five consecutive cycles, outperforming several conventional solid acid catalysts in terms of recyclability, including Amberlyst-15 [49], SBA-15–SO₃H [50], sulfonated carbon (Guo et al., 2015), H-ZSM-5 [34], and Nafion–SiO₂ [17]. These results highlight the exceptional efficiency, robustness, and sustainability of MKL-SO₃, underscoring its strong potential as a cost-effective and environmentally responsible alternative in acetal synthesis. To further evaluate the intrinsic efficiency of the MKL-SO₃ catalyst, the catalytic activity was normalized to the estimated density of active –SO₃H groups. Based on EDS data, the catalyst contains approximately 0.77 mmol –SO₃H/g, corresponding to 0.077 mmol of acid sites in the standard reaction (100 mg of catalyst). Given a 98 % conversion of 3 mmol benzaldehyde, this results in an estimated turnover number (TON) of ∼38, indicating that each sulfonic group facilitated the formation of nearly 38 molecules of acetal under the applied conditions. This high specific activity reinforces the effectiveness of the functionalization strategy and the accessibility of Brønsted acid sites within the catalyst structure. 4 Conclusions The findings present in this work open new opportunities for investigating the wide-ranging applications of waste in catalysis and green chemistry, with an emphasis on the conversion of waste into high-value compounds and augmenting reaction yields. This work highlights the potential of utilizing a green and efficient kaolin waste-derived catalyst for chemical reactions under room reaction conditions. The characterization results indicated satisfactory thermochemical treatment and functionalization of the kaolin waste, confirming the impregnation of sulfonic groups into the material’s surface. A notable yield of acetals, achieving 98 %, emphasizes the feasibility of employing room temperature conditions for efficient acetals synthesis. The substantial acetal yield, along with the structural and compositional insights presented, underscores the promising potential of kaolin waste as a catalyst in organic chemical processes. coredata.dc:description: In this study, kaolin waste was functionalized with sulfonic groups to enhance its textural and chemical properties, resulting in a high-performance heterogeneous catalyst. The functionalized material was thoroughly characterized using various techniques, including FTIR, XRD, TGA, BET (N2-physisorption), and TEM-EDX. The incorporation of sulfonic groups introduced active sites that significantly increased the ion exchange capacity, thereby enhancing the catalytic performance. When employed as a catalyst in the acetalization of benzaldehyde, the functionalized kaolin waste achieved a remarkable conversion rate of 98 % under optimized conditions. The successful transformation of kaolin waste into a highly effective catalyst demonstrates its potential for broader applications in green chemistry, particularly in sustainable synthesis. Acetals, the target products, are crucial intermediates in organic synthesis and the pharmaceutical industry. The catalytic process proposed in this study offers an efficient and environmentally friendly approach to acetal formation, advancing the field of heterogeneous catalysis. Additionally, extending the application of this functionalized material to other challenging reactions could further highlight its versatility and potential as a sustainable catalyst in various industrial processes.
